title: What is the significance of the internal compass in Magic according to Pitagora?
first_phrase: In the previous section, the author explained the dual nature of the inner rudder in magic, the transcendent self, which is both immediately present and profoundly remote in the worlds of the essence and the phenomena. This inner self, often concealed under personal and social veneers, can become a formidable obstacle or a precious ally in magical practice. In the last 200 tokens, the author provides additional guidance on magical practices, such as the importance of silence and the permissible foods during purifications. The author also introduces the concept of "Auriga intelligenza," or the intelligent charioteer, as a suitable metaphor for magic, raising questions regarding the nature of intelligence's role in magical practices.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the meticulous teachings of Pythagoras to his disciple encompass much more than mere worldly wisdom, as they are also essential - even in the smallest of details - for a successful path in High Magic. The concepts presented, such as the importance of silence and the purification days, serve as practical tools for those seeking to improve their spiritual journey, even if certain ambiguities still persist about the nature of intelligence and the afterlife.
